H0.text: Rivers flooding along a coastal plain are the most likely cause of the difference between sharp, pointed mountain tops and smooth, rounded mountain tops.

H1.text: Erosion and weathering caused the difference between sharp, pointed mountain tops and smooth, rounded ones.

H2.text: Earthquakes and waves are the most likely cause of the difference between sharp, pointed mountain tops and smooth, rounded ones.

H3.text: Rocks melted underground by lava are the most likely cause of the difference between the sharp, pointed tops of some mountains and the smooth, rounded tops of others.

A4.text: Glacial erosion controls the maximum height of mountains, as the relief between mountain peaks and the snow line are generally confined to altitudes less than 1500 m.

A5.text: The erosion caused by glaciers worldwide erodes mountains so effectively that the term glacial buzzsaw has become widely used, which describes the limiting effect of glaciers on the height of mountain ranges.
